member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Configuration.Direction
member.summary: Direction where an object is looking at.
member.remarks: The directions are named/valued after how they look like due the game client. That means, when a character looks to south, it looks straight downwards. Because the map is rotated on the game client, that's actually a corner. Since we use the value 0 as 'Undefined' and the original game client uses value 0 as 'West', this has to be considered when communicating with it.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Configuration.GameMapDefinition
member.summary: Configuration of a map. Contains all information to create an instance of a GameMap.
member.remarks: Some maps have different possible status, for expample the crywolf map: 1) Balgass is undeafeated - monsters are not dropping special items 2) Balgass is defeated - monsters are dropping special items 3) Crywolf event is ongoing - The normal monsters are not there(?), but event monsters. For each of this status (), there exist different terrain maps (safezones are different, etc.). To reflect this requirement on this data model, for each status there must be one game map definition. The switch between this status and its corresponding game map definitions should be done in game logic.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Configuration.GameServerEndpoint.AlternativePublishedPort
member.summary: Gets or sets the alternative published network port. It's reported to the connect server instead of the , if not 0. This allows to run a network analyzer program as a proxy, which listens to this and forwards to without changing the connection address of the game client. This may also be useful if you use port forwarding over NAT.

member.summary: Gets or sets the ancient set discriminator.
member.remarks: Only relevant to ancient sets. One item can only be in one ancient set with the same discriminator. The original mu online protocol supports up to two different ancient sets per item - with discriminator values 1 and 2. E.g. a 'Warrior Leather' set would have a discriminator value of 1, the 'Anonymous Leather' set would have 2.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Configuration.MonsterDefinition
member.summary: A definition for a monster (or NPC in general).

member.summary: Gets or sets the unique number of this monster.

member.summary: Gets or sets the designation of this monster. Not relevant for the server, however helpful for debugging/logging.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Configuration.MonsterDefinition.MoveRange
member.summary: Gets or sets the range in which a monster will move randomly from its current position. This value determines the maximum distance (in tiles) a monster can move in any direction during random movement. Used by the Monster's RandomMoveAsync method. Common values: 3 (typical monsters), 50 (Chaos Castle monsters).

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Configuration.MonsterDefinition.AttackRange
member.summary: Gets or sets the attack range in which the monster can attack without moving closer to the target.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Configuration.MonsterDefinition.ViewRange
member.summary: Gets or sets the view range in which the monster can recognize its targets.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Configuration.MonsterDefinition.MoveDelay
member.summary: Gets or sets the move delay for each step.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Configuration.MonsterDefinition.AttackDelay
member.summary: Gets or sets the attack delay, which is the time between attacks.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Configuration.MonsterDefinition.RespawnDelay
member.summary: Gets or sets the delay which is waited until a died instance respawns.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Configuration.MonsterDefinition.Attribute
member.summary: Gets or sets the attribute value. This appears to be a legacy field from the original MU Online protocol. In the codebase, it's typically set to 2 (312 occurrences), with occasional values of 0 or 1. This field is not actively used in game logic or sent in network packets, but is preserved for data completeness and potential future use. The original purpose is unclear - possibly related to visual effects or monster behavior flags.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Configuration.MonsterDefinition.NumberOfMaximumItemDrops
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of maximum item drops after an instance of this monster died.

member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the intelligence type, if this npc/monster uses a specific implementation of an INpcIntelligence.

member.summary: Gets or sets the skill with which this monster is attacking. Also known as "Attack type".
member.remarks: The additional damage of the skill is usually NOT applied; However, magic effects are.

member.summary: Gets or sets the monster type definition which defines behavioral characteristics. This allows data-driven configuration of monster behavior patterns. If null, the monster uses default behavior based on its other properties.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Properties.Resources.SystemConfiguration_IpResolver_Description
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Defines how the own ip address is determined. It's reported back to the game client in case it requests to connect to a selected game server (server selection screen) or the chat server (when starting a chat with the in-game messenger). This may be helpful, if the server is started in an environment where the public IP is not reachable from the outside (e.g. because you share your IPv4-Address or behind a firewall) and you want to use it within your computer or private network..
